Powerful magnetic floors combined with adjustable magnetic spacewear.

That way, you can adjust the suit's magnetic pull to match your earth weight. In fact, you'd be able to make your suit a little heavier every day, week, or month, and actually build muscle as you go.

Of course, in designing the suit, you'd have to consider the effects of the magnets to the iron, and/or any other ferromagnetic materials in our blood/body. It's possible that it would require magnetic implants, and/or some kind of reusable magnetic pill that you swallow every day, after discharging and sterilizing it, (and, for those of you who do not already know, they do already clean and drink their urine in space. Water is heavy and irreplaceable there. Every drop is reused, over and over, again and again, until they get back to earth.), or maybe just an ejection to nuteralize your blood stream, or something [to counteract the magnetic pull from both the suit and the floor].

Of course, I have absolutely no idea what I'm talking about. [It's likely not possible, for any number of reasons]. I just smoked some great weed, and thought, 'I know..!', and here we are.

But, whether you're a celebrated physicist, an unemployed homeless person, or any[one] between the two, I'd love to know what you think about the "magnetic suit theory".

Obviously, the more you know on the subject of magnets, and it's effects on the human body, the better. But, I only have a sixth grade education, and all I know about magnets is what I learned in school, so who cares. Chances are, whatever your knowlage on them, you're likely to know more than me, [not that that even matters].

It's actually building the technology and robotic machines to make the parts to produce a technologically complex product, so it's like cooking really, it takes 3 hours to cook a decent roast dinner, but only takes 10 minutes to eat it.
So it's not the design itself, it's the technology that's makes the technology and technically advanced machines that make the technology to make a particularly complex product.
Evolution, everything evolves, everything from biological life to an idea, a design, prototype, or technology demonstrator, a production process, then a product, then making that product tye best it can be by continuously upgrading or improving on the original.
So don't reinvent the wheel, just reinvent the way we improve how to produce it , making it a more efficient, more durable streamlined, easier to manufacture and maintain design and product, and over time all the above ends up making them easier and cheaper to produce, simplifying as much as possible to create just an altogether better version of the original creation.

My flight and space class went to Starbase all the way in November and had a tour too! It was super cool!!!!! They showed us how they cut stainless steel, weld them into rings, and stack them on each other. Then they showed us the nosecones or tops of the rockets, then they showed us their heat shield tiles! They felt like bricks, but they are immensely light. They showed us how they put them on the starships with that white layer on top of the steel. They showed us the tall bay, and other bays. Then we walked through the stargate building, came out the other side, and walked to the place near the two starships which I forgot their names of, and ended the tour there. Also, Starbase looked different compared to the video, our teacher told us the area literally changes every day! I've wanted to be an aerospace engineer since 3rd grade!



In case you don't believe me (not a flex) I still have the sticker they gave to everyone in our class!

Dear Tim, you both talk a 7:39 about something that might seem small and not-so-important, the incredibly noisy environment, and SPECIFICALLY the beeping sounds of vehicules backing off. By the end of thi segment, Elon has signified his annoyance several times, and he should... For my part, one hour of beeping got me simply nauseous and I was very happy when this part ended... :-/

Elon says he's not sure that those actually "help"... Well, it IS not helpful at all, (IKR, how obvious) and there are actually very scientific studies which amply demonstrate that it is more dangerous than beneficial in fact, on top of being a serious psychological nuisance in the long term.
Why more dangerous than anything? Because people simply stop paying attention at some point... How could they not?? It's permanent.

If Mr Musk has your attention, I think it might be a pretty solid point to address to him, as I'm fairly certain that he is smart enough (such an understatement) to understand the value it could bring in terms of safety and improvement of working conditions : vehicules backing off should not have constant beeps but PROXIMITY BEEPS, like when you park your car... Those "accelerating" beeps, turning to constant noise when danger is real close, THAT, you dont lose focus of, and THEY are a really useful information for our brains and safety... I guess such topic might need to be brought to HOSHA, but then so be it.

The highlight of this interview are Elon Musk's five steps to improve the manufacturing process.

Opening comments:

@3:50 currently manufacturing is underrated and design is overrated;
@3:55 people generally think that there is this Eureka moment, like you came up with this idea and that’s it...

The five-step process:
@13:36 Step 1: make your requirements less dumb (it does not matter who gave them to you. it's particularly dangerous if a smart person gave you the requirements because you might not question them enough. everyone is wrong some of the time);
@15:58 Step 1 (b): whatever requirement or constraint you have, it must come with a name, not a department (the person must take responsibility);

@13:56 Step 2: try very hard to delete the part, or the process (if you are not occasionally adding things back in, you are clearly not deleting enough);

@17:18 Step 3: simplify or optimize (the most common error of an engineer is to optimise a thing that should not exist);

@21:30 Step 4: accelerate cycle time (you are moving too slowly, go faster);

@21:57 Step 5: automate.

anecdote
@22:00 "I have personally made the mistake of going backwards on all five steps multiple times..."

It seems to me that launching a bunch of ships with nothing but fuel is kind of a waste of time and energy. Elon‘s philosophy of the best part being no part is the secret to the whole refuel problem. I came up with an idea that just seems incredibly simple so I will assume that somebody else has already come up with it and they decided it wasn’t feasible or it’s already being considered. So at the risk of coming off like an idiot let me give you my suggestion. For decades science fiction has talked about a space elevator, the idea is based on the centripetal force of the earths rotation holding the end up in place. But that idea is kinda pointless and will take way too much effort, but a couple of pipes going up to supply an orbital gas station would be a lot cheaper and easier. The pressure at the earth end of the pipes should be reduced to some degree by the centripetal force of The liquids at the top pulling. Prior to now any type of space elevator contraption would have to be built from the ground up but now with starship it could easily be built from the top down, just drop down a rope and have somebody pull the pipes down to the supply platform. This would eliminate the need for launching tankers fully loaded with fuel into space. All that you would have to launch is empty containers that can be filled later after they get to orbit. A refueling system in orbit would illuminate the need for heat tiles and fins for reentry as you could refuel before coming back and just use the Rockets to slow down, saving all the weight of the Finns and tiles. The base platform could be out to sea away from people and equatorial (if that matters) and be easily supplied using existing ships. This would allow a lot more playing around in space, just rent one of Elon’s portable tanks and go mine that asteroid. He could make money supplying other companies ships if they’re smart enough to use methane. I’m no engineer but if this works it could be a total game hanger for humanity. I’m assuming that this already in the works or discarded because it won’t work.

In software engineering the brightest developers for all their genius often fail to deliver because they are so focussed on engineering everything to the nth degree they end up in a never ending loop of going back and forth and if they finally deliver a working product it's too late, too expensive, out of date and totally overengineered. Elon's 5 steps of engineering, starts at about 13:30 (paraphrased)
1. Make the requirements less dumb. Requirements are always dumb and lacking. It is especially dangerous if a smart person made the requirements, as they might not be questioned enough. Everyone is wrong some of the time. All requirements and constraint must be linked to a person who takes responsibility for the requirement (not a department). You must always be able to track down the author and someone who will defend it.
2. Try very hard to delete the part or process. If you are not occasionally adding things back in you are not deleting enough. There is a strong bias towards "let's add this in case we need it", but you can make just in case arguments for so many things. When doing something difficult you need to run tight margins. Because if you don't run tight margins you won't have a chance of achieving your goals. You can't hedge your bets
3. Simplify or optimize
4. Accelerate cycle time. You are moving too slowly. Move faster. Don't work on going faster before you have worked on the previous 3 steps.
5. Automate. This is the final step for a reason.

For a nice USA equivalent (from forgotten weapons on YouTube) you can build a perfectly operational machine gun in several months. However this is a one off one of a king weapon and all parts are hand fit. So then you sell this to the USA army. Now it takes 10 years or more to actually make the machine gun a production line weapon that a factory can build. Things like ‘how can you get a CNC to machine this bit. When it’s done have we introduced any anomalies? The. What’s the tolerance on every part such that the gun can be built in any factory and have parts from one factory drop into a gun from another factory (especially with the AK47) and so on. It’s 10 years or more on average to do this, take it from a one off and into a production line product assuming you can even manage it at all.

An example of ‘oops what the Hellhiem is going on here’ is the 7th round stoppage on the M1 Garand of WW2 fame. Turns out if the rounds were loaded left right left instead of right left right, or the other way around. As well as a machining error where to cut one slot or grove in the bolt and if the machinist went to fast aka too far then this tiny nub was cut away and then sometimes combined with the order the rounds were loaded then you may get a stoppage. At the weapon open day at the trials where news paper and magazine writers had a chance to fire the guns this problem wasn’t solved. The workaround of round loading order was figured out but the problem it solved was still unknown. So all the ammo clips were loaded by a single army guy and they were all loaded perfectly for the dodgy fix. At this time the M1 Garand was still not a certainty for acceptance.

So yeah, turning a smart or brilliant int idea into repeatable reality is difficult. It’s also very good that a person of the caliber of Elon Musk acknowledges this. Imagine his workers hearing this or the workers family and friends hearing this, they would be so proud to have their contributions recognised as being essentially important. That’s how you achieve loyalty in a workforce and subsequent dedication.

Question: Why not scale up Falcon 9 vs building a brand new ship from scratch?

Falcon 9's boosters are operational, reliable, reusable, and battle tested. If they attached 5 boosters (4aux and 1 main totaling 45 Merlins) to a Falcon 9 they would get ~250,000lb LEO payload, similar to the Starship target.

All they'd need to do is make a longer Falcon 9 ship, shuttle additional boosters to LEO staging, and away they go to Moon and Mars. No brand new platform and risks required...

Do we really need the reusable Starship right now? It never makes sense to land the whole Starship on the moon so a lander will be needed and a source to fuel the landers. Consequently stage 1 would be reusable and stage 2 would be a "cheap" fuel tank with a cheap engine that would take it to orbit. We need spare fuel in interesting orbits (moon transfer / mars transfer). This way we could go to moon / mars already now and only develop capability to come back in the future. e Automate

My personnel belief is that the best way to get to mars and get out into space in general, is a base on our moon first. (Or a Starbase in a high orbit) Because launching from the moon to mars requires FAR less fuel than trying to launch from the surface of earth. A Starbase freefloating on its own would need constant nonstop resupply missions for literally everything. A base on the moon could be build underground, with absolutely every component created in 3d lazer printers, using the material available on the moon already as the "Medium" for the lazer printers. Meaning build the moon base almost entirely out of material already found on the moon. And at some point in the future, the moon base with be established and flourishing to the point of being able to launch deeper missions into the abyss

Engineering lessons from Elon (notes from the interview)...
step 1 make your requirements less dumb
step 2 delete the part or process 10% of the time, then if you are not adding things back in at least 10% of the time, you're not deleting enough
step 3 simplify or optimize , most common mistake of the engineer is to optimize the thing that should not exist. Mental straight jacket comes from educational system where you have to answer the professor's question rather than telling him the question is dumb.
step 4 accelerate cycle time - go faster, but if you're digging your grave, don't dig it faster
step 5 automate

-The vacuum and the atmosphere optimized engines are because of the diameter of the circumference and the length of the cone.
Then why don't make like the fighter planes and make the cone move so it's always on the optimal diameter?

Explanation: I know rocket engines are powerful and they need one piece heat resistant cones with refrigeration to prevent them from melting. But it you cut the cone of the engine into 8-10 parts and then make them fit so thrust doesn't escape from holes between the parts and move them along side the rocket while it's flying you can make them have a smaller diameter while launching for peak water level efficiency and then make the move with servos/hydraulics "must have enough strength to prevent the parts from separation while allowing them to fold and open like petals of a flower" so it gets wider and keeps the efficiency along side the altitudes increases. That wait even thought it's adding a lot of moving parts to the "already complicated" engine but it might allow you to have more cargo "more power thanks to increased efficiency"/have more flying time because you are at peak efficiency all the way from water level to space and while dropping you could also manipulate the thrust this way at the landing stage.

It would be like having the atmosphere and the space optimized engines in one + all the steps between.

Also that might be the answer to have peak efficiency at different atmosphere levels like earth, moon, mars and the perturbations in space.

I have a rule just implement rigorously. It’s a five step process

1. Make your requirements less dumb. Your requirements definitely dumb. It doesn’t matter who gave them to you. It's particularly dangerous if a smart person gave you the requirements because you might not question them enough. Everyone’s wrong no matter who you are.

2. Try very hard to delete the part or process. If you’re not adding things back in, you are not leading enough. The bias tends to be very strongly towards let’s add this part or the process step in case we need it. But you can basically make in case arguments for so many things.

3. Simplify or optimize. The most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize the thing that should not exist.

4. Accelerate cycle time. If you’re moving too slowly, go faster.

5. Automate everything.

Elon Musk way of Product developing
5 Steps [13:32]
1. Step [13:36]: Make your requirements less dump (Make an employee responsible for every detail not an department.) (Everyone's wrong some of the time.)
2. Step [13:57]: Try very hard to delete the part or process (very important)(Everyone adds something in case it might be needed.)(Model 3 Fiberglass mat above battery)(If you are not adding back in 10% of the things, you are not deleting enough.)
3. Step [17:20]: Simplify or optimize (Step 1&2 must come first.)(In an exam you can't tell a professor your question is dumb.)
4. Step [21:31] Accelerate cycle time (Work on Step 1&2&3 first.)
5. Step [21:57]: Automate
Example [22:03] ,,I have personally made the mistake of going backwards on all five steps multiple times."(Tesla Model 3) [25:46]
Don't forget to remove the in-process tests, if you have an end-test.

5 step process: (13:30)

1. Make your requirement less dumb. (13:35)

Your requirements are definitely dumb. It does not matter who gave it to you. It is particularly dangerous if a smart person gave you the requirements because you might not question them enough. Everyone is wrong, no matter who you are. Everyone is wrong some of the time
Whatever requirement or constraint you have, it must come with a name (of a person), not a department. You cannot ask the department. You have to ask the person. The person that puts forward the requirement must take responsibility for the requirement (16:00).

2.Try very hard to delete the part or process. (13:56)

If you are not occasionally adding things back in, you are not deleting enough. This is particularly important if you are running tight margins. If in doubt, try adding the part or process later.
If you are not adding things back in 10% of the time, you are clearly not deleting enough. (17:08)
It is a very common error of a smart engineer to optimize a thing that should not exist (17:30)

3. Simplify or optimize (17:20)

4. Accelerate cycle time (21:30)
You're moving too slowly. Go faster, but don't go faster until you've worked on the other three things first.

5. Automate (21:58)

Elon's 5-step process

1. Make your requirements less dumb - doesn't matter who gave them to you. Question them. If they're from a smart person, that's worse - because you won't question them enough. Requirement/Constraint must come with a name - someone who's responsible for.
2. Try very hard to delete part/processes-step. You can't hedge your bets. That's why the grid fins don't fold back. (Something we can add later). If you're not adding things back in 10% of the time, you're not deleting enough.
3. Simplify/Optimise - Engineers often optimise something that shouldn't exist. (Convergent logic - we're told in school to answer the question, not question the question)
4. Accellerate cycle time - you're going to slowly, go faster. (Because now you're in the right direction - you're not digging your own grave)
5. Automate.

5 Step Process
1. Make your requirements less dumb. (Especially if it's from a smart person)
1.5. Whatever requirement you have, it must come with a name, not a department. (That person must take responsibility for it)
2. Try to delete requirements and processes. (You should be occasionally adding things back in)
3. Optimize (It's a mistake to optimize something that shouldn't exist)
4. Accelerate cycle time (You're moving too slow, but don't accelerate until finished above steps)
5. Automate (Make sure you automate last)

Bonus:
- Remove development testing steps when moving to production.

Elon’s 5 Step Process (from this video)


1.) Make your requirements less dumb

2.) Delete the part or process step

It’s particularly dangerous if a smart person gave you the requirements because you might not question them enough. Everyone’s wrong no matter who you are, everyone’s wrong some of the time. If you are not occasionally adding things back in, you aren’t deleting enough. The bias is “Let’s add this part or process step in case we need it.” You have to run at tight margins, if you don’t you won’t get anything into orbit.

Whatever requirement or constraint you have, it must come with a name, not a department. You can’t ask the department, you have to ask a person. The person who is putting forward the requirement or constraint, they must take responsibility for that requirement. Otherwise you could have a requirement that an intern 2 years ago randomly came up with off the cuff and they aren’t even at the company anymore — but it came from the X department — yet nobody at the X department currently agrees with that.


3.) Simplify or optimize
This is the third step, not the first or second step. Possibly the most common of a smart engineer is to optimize a thing that should not exist.


4.) Accelerate cycle time
You’re moving too slowly — go faster. But don’t go faster until you’ve worked on the other 3 things first. If you’re digging your grave, don’t dig it faster — stop digging your grave. You can always make things go faster.


5.) Automate
Elon’s personally made the mistake of going backwards on all 5 steps — multiple times. On the Model 3 He automated, accelerated, simplified, and then deleted. One example is fiberglass mats on the top of the Model 3 battery packs in between the floor pan and the battery and it was one point choking the battery pack production line. He was basically living on the battery pack production line trying to fix the line because it was choking the entire Model 3 production program. The first mistake was he tried to fix the automation — he tried make the robot better, making them move faster, shorter paths, increase the torque, etc. Instead of spackle and glue on the entire battery pack, just put little dabs of glue because the fiberglass mats are sandwiched between the battery pack and the floor plan anyways, so all you need is something to hold them in place until you bolt the whole battery pack into the car.

So automating was a mistake, then accelerating was a mistake, then optimizing was a mistake. The finally he asked “what the heck are these mats for?” and asked the Battery Safety team and if they were for fire protection or something? They said no, they are for noise and vibration — and he said “but you’re the battery department” — so he asked the Noise and Vibration Analysis team what it’s for and they said “Fire safety.”

Finally he said “Let’s try a car with the fiberglass mats and without, and put microphone in both and see if you can tell the difference.” And you cannot — in fact, I was like “Which one is which?” So we just deleted them — and just bypassed this complete $2 million robot cell.

nobody is really thinking this through all the way what a EV transition will really mean. To start with, where are those billions of dollars in fuel taxes going to come from to maintain our highways when people just plug their cars in for 'fuel'? Then you have a charging infrastructure which needs to be as plentiful as it is today with gas stations. and that means out in rural, desolate areas, not just along major highways and cities. Then are we really going to have a dozen different types of charging connections and charging specifications? The gas station itself will need to phase out as people will need to charge where they shop and work, not just stop at a corner station of a 5 min fuel up. Then we will thousands of displaced auto mechanics and technicians, that if the theory holds up, EVs will need far less routine maintenance and far fewer mechanical breakdowns. Add to that Fire and rescue will need to be trained on all aspects of EVs in crashes, electrical fires, hazardous chemical spills, etc.. The government right now is mostly focused on paying people to buy a Union made EV and that is about it

Developers, Designers, Project/Product Managers, here are your ultimate 5 steps.

1. Make your requirements less dumb, requirements from smart people are dangerous because you might not question them.
2. Try hard to delete the part or process step which is not at all needed or creates extra efforts to be executed.
3. Don't optimize things that should not exist.
4. Accelerate Cycle time, if you are going slower, go faster, but don't go faster until you have completed the first 3 steps,
5. Automate the five steps above.

The SI units like Pascal and Newtons are useful for defining units in terms of other units without any conversion factors, so you don't need to keep track of conversion factors when doing calculations. E.g. force is pressure per area, so 1 Pascal = 1 Newton / 1 square meter. So for calculations, using the SI units is useful and then just convert back to what makes intuitive sense afterwards, since it's metric it's just powers of 10 anyway (e.g. 1 bar = 10 kPa). Pascal and Newton are not "dumb", they make sense in some contexts, but of course that doesn't mean you should express all forces in and pressures in Newton and Pascal all the time. I'm a particle physics we express energies and masses in GeV (Giga Electronvolt) because those make sense for particles (mass of a Proton ~ 1 GeV), but nobody goes around explaining the Kilograms and Joules are dumb, they are just not useful for talking about particles.

Elon's 5 steps matches those you see in successful SW development and I guess one would would also see correlations with other industries and processes.

SW: Keep It Simple Stupid; Requirements Ownership and traceability; Don't over optimise too early (if at all - stop digging); Improve cadence of development (Agile and prototyping); and Automate production (Testing, Static Analysis, Provability, Continuous Integration and Delivery (DevOps)). Expect failures and make sure you have implemented features that allow you to understand and learn from them.

I have also found that successful projects are usually driven by key management that are both informed and passionate about their field - willing to delegate but maintain and amazing ability to stay in touch with the nuts and bolts of the creation of the final product - Elon would be your dream boss.

Elon Musk Quotes:
"All designs are wrong, it’s just a matter of ‘how wrong.’"

His 5 step process:
1. Make your requirements less dumb. (Your requirements are definitely dumb, it is a matter of who gave it to you.. it is particularly dangerous if a smart person gave you, as you might not question them enough. Any requirement you have must come with a name, not a department)
2. You’ve got to delete the part or process step (Constantly evaluate and remove things that are good to have or a plan b or a hedge.. if you are not adding 10% all the time, then you are not deleting enough!)
3. Simplify or Optimize (the most common thing of a smart engineer is to optimize a thing that should not exist!)
4. Accelerate cycle time (you are moving too slowly, go faster. But don’t go faster until you have worked on the first 3 steps first)
5. Automate.

Methane on the Moon
I have often heard that Elon Musk really blew it by using Methane instead of Hydrogen to fuel his huge Starship Rocket because the Moon is loaded with hydrogen containing water and is completely devoid of methane.

Well, not really.

While Methanol does not exist naturally on the Moon it would be expedient to synthesise it. That could be accomplished thusly.

Once volatiles are extracted from lunar regolith, large quantities of Carbon Monoxide (CO) will be released, together with a large quantity of Hydrogen. Both hydrogen and CO are difficult to store. Methanol (liquid methane) is produced by heating hydrogen and carbon monoxide to 644 K in the presence of certain catalysts. Musk probably already knows that it could be very efficient indeed to use Methanol as fuel for Starship.

Doing things differently, keeping it simple, removing red tape and keeping cost and efficiency in the forefront is key. Development of a new system requires plenty of resources and the understanding that you're going to make mistakes. Learning from those mistakes and continuously refining your processes improves the entire development process. Always remember to measure twice and cut once, find out you missed something, what you did not know you did not know and fail, get back up, redesign so that the failure never happens again. Exploring a new frontier means trial and error until you get it right. SpaceX and the fundamentals that Elon Musk is practicing in the development of the StarShip Rocket will bring success with plenty of redundancy. SpaceX, an organization more flexible than NASA will most likely get mankind to Mars far sooner than ever imagined.

Elon’s 5 step process explained in terms of rocket building, but relatable to building any product or business:

1. Make your requirements less dumb (your requirements are definitely dumb, make them less so)

2. Try very hard to delete the part or process (If you’re not adding 10% of deleted things back in, you’re not deleting enough)

3. Simplify or optimize (this is third because the most common error of a smart engineer/person is to optimize a thing that should not exist)

4. Accelerate cycle time (now that 1-3 are handled, you’re moving too slowly, go faster)

5. Automate the part or process

5 step process at 13:30:
1. Make your requirements less dumb: Question everything no matter who said/wrote it.
2. Delete a part of the process: If you are not bringing things back in, you are not deleting enough.
3. Simplify or Optimize: Don't optimize something that should not exist.
4. Accelerate cycle time: Go faster. But after you did the previous 3 steps.
5. Automate: Robots. Avoid automating an inefficient process.

Elon dropped some golden gems during this interview that can be applied to any industry

Elon’s 5 step process

1 - make your requirements less dumb

Your requirements are definitely dumb - no matter who gave them to you. Especially if a smart person gave them to you cause then you may not question them enough

Whatever requirement or constraint you have - must come with a name not just a department and they must take responsibility for that requirement.

2 - try very hard to delete the part or process

The best part is no part and the the best process is no process.

If you’re not occasionally adding things back in (10% of time)then you’re not deleting enough. Bias always is - let’s add this step or process in case we need it.

Example: If things are getting end of line and passing then you don’t need to do in-process testing.

3 - simplify or optimize

Possibly the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize a thing that should not exist.

4 - accelerate cycle time

You’re moving too slowly - go faster. But don’t go faster until you have worked on the other three things.

If you’re digging your grave, then don’t dig it faster. Stop digging your grave.

5 - automate

You can make the mistake of going backwards on all 5 steps, multiple times.

Example: Fiberglass mats in between the battery pack and body on a Tesla. Elon improved the automation. Reduced the process be simplifying how they were glued on. Then asked the question what these mats were for. Battery team said they were for noise reduction and the other team thought they were for fire protection. So they tested sound and removed the pads.

Elon's way sounds better somehow, perhaps because that other one is used so much by people who just don't pay attention or don't care to do a good job and use that as an excuse to say we're all the same or equal.

Steps:
1-- Make your requirements less dumb or stupid

2-- Delete the process or part. If you're not adding things back in at least 10% of the time, you're clearly not deleting enough.

3-- Simplify or optimize. The THIRD step, NOT THE FIRST ONE... the REASON is the third step is because it is very common, possibly the most common error of a smart engineer, is to optimize the thing or process that should not exist in the first place. 
So WHY would they do that?? Everyone's been trained in high school or college, that you got to answer the questions, CONVERGENT logic; so you cant tell a professor Your question is dumb. You'll get a bad grade. you HAVE TO answer the question. So everyone's basically without knowing, they got a mental straight jacket on, that they'll work on optimizing the thing that should simply not exist.

4-- Finally you get to Accelerate cycle time. You're moving too slowly, go faster. But don't go faster until you worked on the other three things first. Or you'll be just digging your grave faster.

5-- And then Automate.

@Crakk Bone suggested earlier on that Musk is a narcissist. I don't think so.

In the interview he admits several times that he is unsure of a number or detail and jokes about mistakes he and SpaceX made in the past. A narcissist would just bullshit and move on to the next brag. He gives credit to the original innovators of the full fuel flow engines, the Russians. A narcissist would claim all the credit.

His ideas about hardware development comes from the world of software engineering which has been using rapid prototyping and iterative development for years. His remarks about testing are right on the mark in my view. Look at Microsoft's recent Windows bugs that were not found until new versions were released. Although the unit tests were probably OK, the final products were severely flawed after integration.

Some ideas that he throws against the wall don't stick however, like the hyperloop, which has too many practical drawbacks to be feasible IMO. These drawbacks include the enormous power requirements for the pumps and the severity and high chance of a catastrophic single point random failure or the chance of deliberately inflicted damage to the system. The cost of hyperloop is great compared to regular high speed rail or mag lev which in themselves are not cheap. Notice that he has passed hyperloop development to others and his test hyperloop is now just a rusty tube alongside the street. Hyperloop was a pet idea that just wasn't thought out enough before he went public with it.

Elon’s (paraphrased) 5 steps of systems engineering:

1. Make your requirements less dumb: It doesn’t matter who gave them to you, question them. Especially if it’s from a smart person—everyone is wrong some of the time.
2. Try very hard to delete a part or process: If you’re not having to add things back in, you haven’t deleted enough.
3. Simplify, not optimize: Convergent logic isn’t always the right way. Some optimized things shouldn’t even exist.
4. Accelerate cycle time: But don’t go faster until you’ve done step 1-3.
5. Automation: the last step, never first!

13:43 + " Implement Rigorously is the 5 step process:

1. Make your requirements less dumb, your requirements are definately dumb. It does not matter who gave them to you, it's particularly dangerous if a smart person gave them to you.

2. Try very hard to delete the part or process - If you're not adding things back in at least 10% of the time you're not removing enough.

3. Simplify or optimise. Don't optimise a thing that shouldn't exist. The most common problem of a smart engineer, is to optimise things that don't exist.

4. Accelerate cycle time. You're moving too slowly, go faster. But don't go faster until you've worked on the other 3 things first.

If you're digging your own grave, don't dig it faster, stop digging your grave. You can always make things go faster.

5. Automate.

Go in this order. Don't automate, simplify, accelerate, then delete. I've made this mistake many times - Elon Musk

I attended GA Tech in the age of the slide rule (early 70's) as an Industrial Engineering major. 1. Make your requirements less dumb (and whatever requirement or constraint you have, it must come with a name, not a department)
2. Try hard to delete the part or process (avoid the bias of adding more to cover your "just in case" scenarios)
3. Simplify or optimize
4. Accelerate cycle time
5. Automate

Elons Design/Manufacturing Process that he implement rigorously:

1) Make your requirements less dumb (Every requirement is dumb, you have to question it enough. Everyone is wrong some of the time)
2) Delete the part or process. (You should be occasionally adding things back in. Bias tends me to add things, not to delete.)
3) Simplify or optimise. (Do above two first, otherwise you will optimise the thing that should not exist)
4) Accelerate cycle time. (After you complete above three first only. You are moving too slowly, go faster)
5) Automate

Around 4:00 - That's because Musk calls every wild idea "design", and them proceed to manufacturing, finds it does not work, re-design, sometimes quite radically, and counts all that as "manufacturing". Take Starship: they actually made carbon fiber articles before figuring out that they are expansive, slow to make and will be difficult to make re-enter safely. Then they came up with evaporative cooling, obviously without proper simulations, before abandoning it (when somebody actually did some calculations) and turning to one of two traditional heat shield technologies (ceramic tiles vs. ablative shield used by Dragon). They learned how to weld on the building site, instead of by reading literature and testing in a workshop/laboratory. Not to mention pressure testing - stainless steel pressure vessels are not, pardon the pun, rocket science - they have been built for a century - everything abut their behavior is well understood. And yer, SpaceX needed experiments, often spectacular.
I am pretty sure that this "catching" concept that went from "landing right into launch clamps" to various designs of legs to its preset incarnation of some king of arms will go through several more iterations. That's "build first, think later" approach - at first glance fast, but actually incredibly wasteful.
Or Raptors - not two of them are same, despite all the testing at McGregor.
Meanwhile, Falcon 9 earns their bread and butter under Shotwell's direction.

There are so many excellent one-liners in here:
3:51 "Manufacturing is underrated and design is overrated."
4:40 "The amount of effort that goes into the design rounds down to zero, relative to the effort that goes into the manufacturing system."
6:12 "How do we make a Raptor where the cost per ton of thrust is under a thousand dollars."
6:20 "The fundamental thing that needs to be fixed is the cost per ton to orbit."
8:22 "It's debatable whether this is the right deign or not. In fact all designs are wrong, it's just a matter of how wrong."
13:36 "First make your requirements less dumb. Your requirements are definitely dumb."
13:51 "No matter who you are, everyone's wrong some of the time."
16:00 "Whatever requirement or constraint you have, it must come with a name, not a department."
17:12 "If you are not adding things back in 10% of the time, you're clearly not deleting enough."
17:30 "Possibly the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize the thing that should not exist."
19:28 "If Edison and Tesla had a baby"
21:06 "Barking up the peroxide tree"
36:53 "Only a fool would use Newtons"
37:26 "Pascal is another trash unit"
(Obviously don't take any of these out of context.)

Elon Engineering in 5 steps. Note: Very important to follow these steps IN ORDER!!!
1. Make your requirement less dumb; and question every requirement; constraint/requirement must have a name (not team or department) that owns it.
2. Try hard to delete part or process; and if you are not adding stuff back in from time to time, you are not deleting enough. Note: Especially true for aerospace engineering due to weight constraint.
3. Simplify or optimise.
4. Accelerate cycle time, I.e. go faster.
5. Automate.
Masterclass by Elon Musk. Valuable lessons from the man himself. Be sure to take notes.

I initially watched this because I was interested in the engineering and production aspects of Space X and Starship, but ended up instead watching it because of Musk and how his mind works – what an extraordinary man. With his struggle to convert his thoughts into speech (but at times also produce incredibly clear and concise insights), and his unconscious mannerisms and reactions (completely ignores the sunset, and ignores Tim's attempts to redirect him when he's still thinking something through - and has an unleashed dog with him as he walks through a crowded working area!), he is a psychologists dream! I've never warmed to Musk, and I don't hold with the idea that, because he clearly has a brilliant mind, everything else he does and says must be right, but watching his mind working and its struggle with the limitations of communicating to the rest of us mere mortals was absolutely fascinating. I'd love to see (for instance) Bezos and Branson 'interviewed' in a similar way - how similar or different would they turn out to be? How much are they hands on and critical to everything like Musk - or do they 'manage' more, and employ others to turn their dreams into reality? I have a feeling that, much as I find Musk's politics and opinions difficult, I would end up warming to him more than Branson, and probably far more than Bezos.

Ian McCollum of "Forgotten Weapons" has in a number of videos explained about the trials/testing/acceptance and production history of certain firearms. He has ALWAYS emphasized that PRODUCTION of firearms is incredibly difficult. So much so that during trials and testing of a new design many times the "better" design proves not to be reproducible at a production scale and that a "worse" design is what we end up with because it is the one you can ACTUALLY build. Fascinating stuff all around.

The five steps
1- make your requirements less dum , your requirements are particularly dum no mater who gave them to you. It's particularly dangerous if a smart person gave you the requirements because you might not question them enough - no mater who you are, everyone is wrong some of the time.
2- Try very hard to delete part of the process.If you are not occasionally adding back in, your not deleting enough.
3- Only after steps one and two are exhausted , simplify or optimize. The common mistake of a smart engineer is to optimize something that should not exist.
4-Accelerate above cycle time, if your moving too slowly go faster.
5-Automate the above

My late Dad was a senior manager at a car production plant (old internal combustion engine types) where he joined after the war when he worked on servicing and maintaining Spitfires.  He used to say that he would be handed the designs for cars and how they were meant to be put together that looked great on paper but were impossible to build on an assembly line !  He would spend a lot of time (and not that much time with me as a consequence) explaining the problems and suggesting other more practical solutions to the designers.  But some of the things Elon was talking about resonated with what my Dad used to talk about.  Design is overrated compared to manufacturing.

Wow Tim! Literally the greatest interview with Musk I've yet seen.

Lesson's in design & manufacturing (the rest is rocket nerdistry)

3:17 - (3 mins) Making things gets difficult AFTER you imagine it. And 1000x harder to make copies quickly
8:22 - (10 secs) all designs are wrong

13:15 - (9 mins) The Five Step Process
Step 1) 13:36 - Make requirements less dumb.
Step 2) 13:52 - Try very hard to delete the part or process
Step 1 again) 15:51 - Requirements must have a name who can answer why it's not dumb.
Step 3) 17:17 - Simplify or Optimize - but not until you prove you can't delete it. (3 minute example)
Step 4) 21:31 - Accelerate Cycle Time
Step 5) 21:55 - Automate

The Dangers of doing the steps backwards.
22:00 - (2.7 mins) Model 3 Battery Blanket.

In Process testing
24:50 - (2 mins) when to not use it.
26:38 - (1.5 mins) A wrong test can add unnecessary problems. Battery water proofing.
32:18 - (1.5 mins) Rapid testing - It must work before optimizing (see step 1&2) Unknown Unknowns

36:28 - (2 mins) Use units that make understanding easier.
38:20 - (1 min) You want everyone to be Chief Engineer
40:38 - (4.3 mins) Attitude Thruster Example of removing a part by knowing the whole system.

45:05 - (3 mins) Elon re-evaluates a design in real-time.

Just letting him talk about lesson's learned and best practices for 40 minutes in his playground where he's most comfortable.. not trying to steer the conversation but just hearing him talk his passions.

A laundry list of "Someday we'll look back and laugh" moments from Elon's Engineering Adventures.

Much of this should be required listening for anyone in design, engineering, planning, manufacturing or any job that ends in a product.
Thank you Tim Dodd.. this one will be in classrooms of the future.

First of all, the video is amazing. Thank you for making this tour possible. Second, could we please give Elon the keys to the planet? I'm not going to compare him to fictional characters like Tony Stark, that wouldn't do him justice. He's just one man, a brilliant one, who has decided to take it upon himself to push the limits of human technological evolution further than ever before. He's a prime example of how an individual can get incredibly rich by simply trying to achieve something greater than wealth. Even if he manages to surpass Bezos, I doubt that he'll ever see money as anything else other than a tool that's required to push technology further and to make it affordable.
I'm not much of a fanboy, but Musk has become the second richest man in history without aiming to become one of the most successful businessmen in history. He simply did his own thing and offered products, services, and technologies that nobody asked for directly but everyone needed. And I honestly don't think that he developed any of them to sell them to the highest bidder.

I honestly think that Elon's units exclusion is stupid (as a whole, it MAY be a good idea in the short run given their speed, but I think its damaging long term regardless). "People don't know what a newton is because they haven't acclimated to it, so lets not use the unit that makes sense, so people never get acclimated to it so it never gets used, so...."
Its a self fulfilling cycle of using stupid units.
Counter Example: Metric machinists going in likely don't know what a micron "is", but they learn/acclimate to it through experience. You ask a practiced machinist what a slip fit should be, and they know instinctively how many microns, what that feels like etc.

Year some base units are stupid small. Doesen't mean that they wouldn't acclimate to the Mega, Giga etc. prefixes We already do that with data.

6:45 "Cost per ton to orbit" "Multi-planet species" Starship hull peeking out of the High Bay assembly building. This is one of those moments that change history. If there are any humans, or our progeny, left in a million years what Space X and Musk are doing right now will be absolutely foundational.
Elon in his busted glass Cybertruck T-shirt, metal banging, vehicle back-up alerts pinging, Starship looking like just a really big DIY project... It's like Robert Heinlein's Rocket Ship Galileo come to life. (Teens building a moon rocket in their backyard.)
I love the moments when Musk has to think for a bit. You can almost hear the fans on the processors speeding up. (Like Battery Day when for just a second he was hyperfocused on the clip of the canning factory.)
At 16 minutes how things get added but not deleted. Basically what Sandy Munro found with the Ford Mach E, a lot of smart engineers but some not very smart things that should've been changed. It's like 10% is I've got a great idea how we're going to do this and then 90% effort trying to eliminate, streamline or combine it. The best part isn't the shiny thing you see, it's the thing that's been eliminated at least twice but is now back because it's the most efficient and reliable way to do something.

1. Make requirements less dumb --
It does not matter who gave these requirements. It is particularly dangerous if a smart person gave the requirements because you then don't question them enough. Everyone is wrong some of the times no matter who they are.

2. Try to delete the part or process --
If you aren't occasionally adding things back in at least 10% of the times, then you are not deleting enough. The biases tends to be "let's add a part or process in case we need it", but there can be countless "in case" arguments made. So you need to have tight margins and don't hedge your bets! Also, whatever requirement or constraint you have, it must come with a name, not a department.

3. Simplify or optimize the part or process --
The most common mistake of engineers is to optimize a thing that should not exist. Everybody is trained in school to must answer the question, to apply convergent logic. You can't ask about quality or origin of the question, otherwise you'll get bad grade.

4. Accelerate cycle time --
You're always moving too slowly, move faster. But don't go faster until you do the other 3 things first. Like, if you're digging your grave, don't dig it faster, rather stop digging!

5. Automate --
But before automating, be aware of the 2 mistakes :
a. Doing automation first -
Automation should be the last step, otherwise you will often end up automating something that should not exist in the first place!
b. Too much in-process testing -
Basically if the process or product is passing the end-process testing successfully, then you don't need to test each and every steps before the end step! It makes process slow, expensive and often a simple in-process test can choke the entire production line. Keep may be one or two in-process tests that are hard to test at the end, and remove everything else.

Amazing series already.l

1 - Make the requirements less dumb.
Your requirements are definitely dumb. It does not matter who gave them to you. It's particularly dangerous, if a smart person gave you the requirements, because you might not question them enough. Everyone's wrong, no matter who you are, everyone's wrong some of the time.
Whatever requirement or constraint you have, it must come with a
name, not a department. 'Cause you can't ask the departments, you have to ask a person, and that person who's putting forward, the requirement or constraint must agree that they must take responsibility for that requirement. Otherwise you could have a requirement that basically an intern two years ago randomly came up with, off the cuff and they're not even have the company anymore.

2 - Delete the part or process
Try very hard to delete the part or process. This is actually very important. If you're not occasionally adding things back in (10%), you are not deleting enough.

3 - Simplify or Optimize the part or process
The reason it's the third step is 'cause it's very common, possibly the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize the thing
that should not exist. And say, well, why would you do that? Well, everyone has been trained in high school and college that you gotta answer the question, convergent logic. So you can't tell a professor,
your question is dumb. You will get a bad grade. You have to answer the question. So everyone is basically, without knowing it, they got like mental straight jacket on that they'll work on optimizing the thing that should simply not exist.

4 - Accelerate cycle time
You're moving too slowly, go faster, but don't go faster until you've worked on the other three things first. If you're digging and you're great, don't dig it faster, stop digging your grave. But you can always make things go faster.

5 - Automate

Another mistake that has to happen in production is too much in-process testing. So when you were first setting up a production line, you don't know where things are breaking. You don't know where things are breaking, so you'll test like working process at various steps and 'cause you wanna isolate where's the mistake occurring?
So a very common issue with production lines is to not remove the end process testing after you diagnose where the problems are. So basically if you have like a very high acceptance, like if things are getting to end of line testing and are passing, then you don't need to do in-process testing. But what used to happened is they'll be like an initial development engineering team that will be like basically debugging the production line, but then they will forget to take out the in-process testing steps. So then what happens is the in-process testing tester will often choke the line production time. So really in volume production, if things are working well, you're really just taking a risk, will this subsystem be rejected in the training production process or at the end.

When you reach the age of 50, you're entitled to get a bit thick in the waist. Before then, though, it's bad form. Elon should probably get a bit more exercise in the sun and fresh air. As the Hank Rearden / John Galt of our age, it's possible that the weight of civilization is riding on his shoulders, whether he knows it or not. His purpose of making humanity a multiplanet species is THE most important purpose for human endeavor. Why? Because it will present a part of humanity, once again, with frontier conditions of living, where the politically correct nonsense that currently plagues Western Civilization on Earth will have to be discarded in order to focus on survival. At the same time, humanity living away from Earth will serve as a repository of technical information that might otherwise be lost, if high-tech civilization falls on Earth.

1. Try to make your requirements less dumb.
Requirements or constraints must be put forth by a single responsible person, not a
department.
Beware requirements put forth by a respected person. Question anyway.
2. Try very hard to delete the part or the process.
If you are not occasionally having to add a part or process back in, you are not trying hard
enough to delete parts and processes.
3. Only then, simplify or optimize
The most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize a part that should not exist (see
step 2). Watch out for the mental straight jacket - the very education of engineers has trained
them to answer questions rather than question questions.
4. Only then, go Faster - (but not before the previous steps - don’t go fast in the wrong direction)
5. Lastly, automate.

Just in case they haven't thought of this yet, please tell Elon:  They're not going to fold the grid fins, so they'll have high-speed airflow through the fins in both directions: up through the fins when the rocket is going down, and down through the fins when the rocket is going up.  Having "teeth" on the leading edge side of the grid fins makes them "work better", as Elon mentioned, so they should have the teeth on both sides of the fin, both the top and the bottom.  They'll want to make the upper teeth 'staggered' in location compared to the bottom teeth so the narrow parts of the steel halfway between teeth aren't in the same place on the top and bottom, to save strength and reduce weight.  Since the fins will be deployed during ascent, they can be used to help steer the rocket then, reducing the amount of engine gimbaling required to maintain heading while still in the atmosphere.

5 step process

step 1. make the requirements less dumb. Your requirements are definitely dumb. Everyone is wrong some of the time

step 2. work hard to delete the part or the process. if you're not occasionally adding things back in 10% of the time, you're not deleting enough, and you can't hedge your bets. step 2(b) a requirement or a constraint must come from a named person who accepts responsibility

step 3. simplify or optimize, do not optimize a thing that should not exist. avoid convergent thinking.

step 4. accelerate cycle time, but not until you work on the first 3 steps first

step 5. automate

Elon's 5 Steps:

1: Make your requirements Less Dumb.
Youre requirements are definately dumb, especially if a smart person gave them to you.

2: Delete the Part or Process Step.
If you're not adding things back in 10% of the time, clearly you're not deleting enough.

3: Simplify or Optimize.
It's possibly the Most Common error of a Smart Engineer, is to Optimize a Thing that should not Exist.

4: Accelerate Cycle Time. Iterate Faster.

5: Automate.

I love the design principles shared here. They're interesting, but I can't help but think they're very centered on developing lines for pioneer tech and sounds like they might be neglecting most or all EOL optimizations like longevity, disassembly and reparability - which I know from second hand experience are common factors in advanced manufacturing. For reusable rockets I guess it makes sense, because they're literally not commercialized yet. But it's a different story for cars, and I hope they are thinking a decent amount about EOL there. J. B. Straubel must be, in some sense, since he's trying to make a company focused on recycling materials, so I hope that means that he wasn't alone, and that it isn't just an afterthought.

Awesome interview, great to hear about what is going on with one of the most important projects that humanity has going.  Sounds like he needs to use some of his Maxwell Ultra-capacitors in combination with Lithium Ion  batteries for a mass optimized power pack capable of operating the grid fins for the short time of their operation.  I have some of these ultra-capacitors, they do not have a good energy density compared to batteries, but they have a pretty good power density.  It seems like it would not be that complicated to optimize a pack made up of both batteries and capacitors to optimize its mass for the power draw of the grid fins for the duration of their deployment plus a safety factor of 1.5 or 2 maybe.  I guess we may end up with 'Dodd' gas thrusters to use up that left over hot gas for attitude control on the Starship . . . . . Seems he is always thinking and iterating.

Extraordinary insight, congrats!
But two things are funny:
You dived so deep into your topic, that you do not realize that this is the worst environment for an interview.
And you show a perfect example for one of Elons mantras: The best part is no part. If you have an alarm signal (for driving back or use a lifting crane etc.) that peeps for hours, it doesn't have an effect anymore - like to make people more aware of a danger. Instead they are just stressed and will not focus as good as without the alarm signal.
Finally: Please wear helmets! If some of the guys up on the crane drops a tool, many of my dreams about the future will have (again) a long delay ;-)

I can't see crewed Starship flights to Mars happening, at least the way existing SpaceX plans have portrayed them.

The logical way to do Mars transits, if orbital refuelling is solved, seems to be with a purpose-built deep space station. Utilizing inflatable habitats, like Bigelow Olympus, you could greatly expand the pressurised volume without being limited by the Starship layout. Redundancy is important, life-support is heavy, crews need adequate space, radiation shielding and additional cargo space are some of the obvious advantages.

You would still use Starships by docking several of them into the station. They could all fire their propulsion systems simultaneously to insert the station to the Mars transfer orbit.

Once the station arrives safely on Mars, the Starships can undock and land with the crew aboard. The station can remain in orbit and provide ground support.

Once the Sabatier process is running the Starship's could even bring additional resources from the station, or refuel & stock the station for the return trip.

That seems like the obvious way to do Mars transits. I'm sure Starships are good for uncrewed missions but it seems like there aren't good arguments supporting crewed solo Starship missions to Mars.

There is a great lesson in this video, implement rigorously. (13:31)
5 steps in order on how to great an effective proces as an engineering team, but also for other tasks that can be improved upon.

1. (13:37) Make the requirements less dumb
2. (13:57) Try hard to delete the part or proces
3. (17:19) Simplify or optimize
4. (21:30) Accelerate cycle time, if moving too slowly go faster
5. (21:56) Automate

Bonus tip1 (15:59): An requirement of constraint should be give by a person not an department.
Bonus tip2 (24:49): To much in-proces testing, mistake is not to remove end proces testing after problems have been taken out.

1. Make requirements less dumb

2. Question the Requirement. Delete the unnecessary part or process step
a. If you are not adding things back into the product at least 10% of the time, you are clearly not deleting enough.

3. Simplify or Optimize
a. (However, the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize a thing that should not exist. Make sure that you don't need to delete a part or process.)

4. Accelerate Cycle Time
a. (You're moving too slowly. Move faster. But don't do this unless you've gone through the first 3 steps. "If you're digging your grave, don't go faster. Stop digging your grave." )

5. Automate


REQUIREMENTS
Whatever requirement or constraint you have, it must come with a name, not a department. You have to ask a person. That person must take responsibility for that requirement.

Sum:
1. Make requirements less dumb (+the wisest the person giving requirements the more you doubt him, +2 every requirement needs a person by name attached to it. not department +3 "All designs are wrong, its just a matter of how wrong")
2. Delete parts or process (if there isn’t some “Re adding of dropped requirements” then you're not deleting aggressively enough.)
3. Simplify or optimize (+A common error of a smart engineer, is to optimize something that shouldn't exist - that is why it is #3)
4. Accelerate cycle time (+remove in-process testing of production after you get the product and test finished product if possible)
5. Automate

13:37 Elon's five step process

1. Make your requirements less dumb. Everyone is wrong some of the time.
2. Try very hard to delete a part or process. If you are not occasionally adding things back in, you are not deleting enough.
3. Simplify or optimize. The most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize a thing that should not exist.
4. Accelerate cycle time. You're moving too slowly, go faster. Test at the end, remove in-process testing.
5. Automate.

The 5 step process Elon is trying to rigorously implement:

1. Make your requirements less dumb. Requirements are definitely dumb. It does not matter who gave them to you it's particularly dangerous if smart person gave you the requirements because you might not question them enough. Everyone's wrong some of the time. What ever requirement or constrain you have it must come with a name not a department. You can't ask a department you have to ask a person. The person putting forward the requirement or constrain they must agree that they must take responsibility for that requirement.
2. Try very hard to delete parts or process. This is very important. If you're not occasionally adding things back in you're not deleting enough. The bias is to be very strongly towards let's add this parts or process in case we need it. You can make in case arguments for so many things. If you're not adding things back in 10% of the time, you're clearly not deleting enough.
3. Simply or optimize. Possibly most common error of a smart engineer is optimizing things that shouldn't exist.
4. Accelerate cycle time. If you're moving too slowly go faster. But don't go faster until you've done first 3 things first. If you're digging your grave don't dig it faster, stop digging lol
5. Automate

Elon's 5 Engineering Principles:
1. Make your requirements less dumb. All requirements are some percentage dumb, and everyone is some percentage wrong all the time. All requirements or constrains must come with a person's name, not the name of a department. Everyone should be empowered to be a lead engineer and should have high-level understanding of the entire system. If anyone has a problem with a constraint, go to that person and question their beliefs.
2. The best part is no part, the best process is no process. If you aren't adding a part or process back in some of the time, you are not deleting enough.
3. Optimization is the third step, not the first step. Even the smartest engineers will work very hard optimizing something that shouldn't exist. Avoid this.
4. You are going too slowly. Accelerate cycle time, but not at the detriment to the first 3 steps.
5. Automate, but not at the detriment of the first 4 steps.

Musk’s Engineering Philosophy:
1. Make the requirements less dumb. The requirements are definitely dumb; it does not matter who gave them to you. It’s particularly dangerous if someone who is smart gives them the requirements, as one may not question the requirements enough. “Everyone’s wrong. No matter who you are, everyone is wrong some of the time, all designs are wrong, it’s just a matter of how wrong.”
2. Try very hard to delete the part or process. If parts are not being added back into the design at least 10% of the time, not enough parts are being deleted. Musk noted that the bias tends to be very strongly toward “let’s add this part or process step in case we need it.” Additionally, each required part and process must come from a name, not a department, as a department cannot be asked why a requirement exists, but a person can.
3. Simplify and optimize the design. This is step three as the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize something that should not exist.
4. Accelerate cycle time. “you’re moving too slowly, go faster! But don’t go faster until you’ve worked on the other three things first.”
5. Automate. An important part of this is to remove in-process testing after the problems have been diagnosed; if a product is reaching the end of a production line with a high acceptance rate, there is no need for in-process testing.
**Elon: “I’ve made the mistake of going backwards. I automated, accelerated, simplified, and then deleted”.

My summary of Elon's 5 Steps
1. Make your requirements less dumb
a. Your requirements are definitely dumb
b. If doesn't matter who gave them [the requirements] to you
c. Especially dangerous if the requirements came from a smart person because you might not question them enough
d. Whatever requirement you come up with must come with a name [person] not a department
i. That person must take responsibility for that requirement [responsibility that the requirement is in a fact required]
ii. Otherwise you end up working on a requirement that was the random idea of an intern that left the company 2 years ago
2. Try very hard to delete the part or process
a. If you are not occasionally added parts back in you are not deleting hard enough
3. Simplify or Optimize the part or process
a. The most common error of a smart engineer is the optimize a part or process that should not exist (see steps 1 & 2)
4. Accelerate Cycle Time
a. you're going too slowly, go faster
b. But only after you have followed steps 1-3
c. Make sure you remove in process test/debug checks that were included during the development stage
5. Automate

I think this could be the single most interesting educational video I've ever seen. For one, eavesdropping on two smart people discussing a complicated subject is always interesting. But, there's something truly special about seeing Musk consider engineering questions he's clearly never thought about before. Whatever someone might say about him, they can't say he's not a brilliant engineer.  Well done for not boring him the way most interviewers do--what you've got here is a special kind of interview. Many engineers could intrigue him, but I think few could make him accessible without dumbing the science down too much. Bravo.

Ok, Elon emphasized how to design.  He said there are 5 things you need to do.  But I came away with seven.  Here's what I captured: 1. Make your requirements less dumb, 2. Try to delete the part or process, 3. All requirements must come with a name (not the department), 4. Simplify or Optimize, 5. Don't optimized something that doesn't need to exist, 6. Accelerate the process, 7. Automate. Can someone clarify this list?  BTW: this is why government committees come up with expensive, overly designed monstrosities when building rockets or weapon systems or anything!

Well, that was very enlightening in seeing why Elon is successful. As an engineer I know how engineers approach a problem, starting with defined constraints which rule out higher decisions. Usually, the people above you in the chain of command think they've imposed the right constraints, but Elon, as the top of the chain of command, is willing to remove constraints, if their removal makes the job easier or saves time and generates a more functional engineering solution. His forte is process analysis, and he has the ability to do it well, and quickly. He also is not ego driven. He's willing to interact with people of all talents to get the job done.

Thanks Tim for the interview. Here's my notes: 1. Make your requirements less dumb (Doesn't matter who gave them to you-Every person can be wrong sometimes)
2. Delete a part or process step (If aren't occasionally adding stuff back in then you are not deleting enough)
3. Optimize or Simplify (Don't optimize a thing the shouldn't exist i.e. step #2)
4. Accelerate cycle time (You're moving to slowly-go faster, but don't go faster if you haven't done step 1,2,3)
5. Automate


Important Principles
* - Whomever gives you a requirement must agree to take responsibility for that requirement.

** - Whatever requirement or constraint you get must come with a name and not a department.

* - To much In-Process testing slows everything. Test at the End if capable.

** - Make everyone a chief engineer - Make People understand the system at high level. To know when they are making at bad optimization in their own process without seeing the big picture.

I suspect Elon's mind functions on the basis of compelling triggers to a greater extent than most because my son is 'on the mild end of the spectrum' for Asperger's and I could not help wondering if Elon is also.

Elon's knowledge and understanding evidently encompass an exceptionally broad range of abilities and capacities that imparts are obviously of significant benefit to his teams and their projects.

It was obvious that when a keyword which is inclusive to any number of interrelated concepts and processes of concern to him were used many if not all relevant considerations began simultaneously impinging upon his attention.

That could not help but be an inconvenient distraction during conversation unless he can maintain or regain focus because everything related to what he is striving to achieve or say is of absorbing interest and concern to him.

That being the case he would of necessity want to provide answers as comprehensively yet succinctly as possible.

Someone subject to such compulsions might be self-conscious regarding the possibility that delays resulting from them might be evident to others.

Consequently they would not want such manifestations erroneously perceived as confusion and embarrassment and that might inhibit conversation which could only exacerbate their discomfort.

This seemed to be evidenced by the obvious pause and change of track after your question regarding the grid fins.

A desire to learn as much as possible and therefore cram in as many questions as possible is understandable.

But a natural conclusion might nonetheless suggest "don't interrupt with premature additional questions if you want more comprehensive responses to any you have already asked".

5 step design process - Elon Musk:
1. Make requirements less dumb. Particularly if provded by smart person. Everyone is wrong, it's a question of how wrong. A person must take responsibility for a requirement or constraint.
2. Delete the part or process step.
3. Simplify or optimize.
4. Accelerate cycle time. If you're moving to slowly, go faster. But do steps 1-3 first, i.e. if you're digging your grave, don't dig your grave.
5. Automate.

You mentioned you are producing a video on Russian rocket engines. I don’t know if you are familiar with this Russian proverb, so I offer it to you so that you understand the Russian heart and mind as it is applied to building things.

Proverb statement:
This Russian proverb incorporates a philosophy that is both wise and true to the Russian heart. Those who have learned to appreciate the Russian character will agree that most Russians instinctively adhere to and follow that philosophy.

To build, to create things good enough to do what they are meant to do is wise; to make them better than necessary is a waste of energy and precious resources.

This article originally appeared in a classified Studies in Intelligence, Vol. 37 No. 3 (Fall 1993). The author received a Studies in Intelligence Annual Award for it in 1994. The article was declassified with slight redactions in 2007.

Unravelling a Cold War Mystery
The ALFA SSN: Challenging Paradigms, Finding New Truths, 1969–79
Gerhardt Thamm

I agree simple purpose specific design is most often economically smarter and that there are so many good designs but you need to go forward with something, now. The point isn't the design, it is to get a working model in action that generates enough cashflow to iterate design optimization later. For example, pigs. Pigs are an endangered species. The only ones we see in quantity have a financial benefit. Meanwhile we still see so much focus on cool things like  moon buggies which while they can have educational benefit, have very little financial benefit compared to say designing an unmanned moon grader, excavator or crane. It is like, the whole industry has been behaving like they don't expect space expansion to happen anytime soon, and SpaceX has opened a better way of thinking but even now the message is taking a while to sink in.

I work on a lot of mass production equipment. Even something as simple as a printed cardboard box requires crazy complicated equipment to produce those boxes in quantity, at a high quality, and do so for years on end. So you end up with a multi million dollar machine to make a cardboard box that may sell for a few cents. THAT is the magic of mass production. The simple fact that economies of scale mean you can make a crazy amount of something very quickly and of a high quality.

So sure, you have to pay a whole lot up front to get the equipment bought, built, and setup. But once you do, it makes you money. A tiny amount at a time, but when you are making production runs of 100's of thousands to millions of things, even a little profit per item actually can make you a tidy profit.

That box printing machine for example, if i am remembering right, at max speed could die cut, print, and glue together 10,000 boxes per hour. So yeah, you may only make a fraction of a cent per box profit, but multiply that by 10,000 per hour, and not only are you making money, but you are providing a very cheap, high quality product that you can sell. And is necessary to ship goods.

Manufacturing and shipping are the two underpinnings of our entire world wide economy.

Knowledge from Elon Musk himself. The 5 Step process of development:


1. Make your requirements less dumb:
no matter who gave them to you, always ask questions and try to understand and make the list of requirements less dumb.

2. Delete as many parts of the process as you can:
Try to work on what really matters the most first, there will always be "what ifs", so reduce as many parts of the process as you can.

3. Amplify and optimize:
It's not the first, nor the second step, it's the third, make the basics first, then focus on optimization the enhancement. And try not to optimize something that does not exist.

4. Step on the accelerator!:
If you think you are going slow, then you are going slow... GOT TO FAST!!!

5. Automate:
If you already passed the first 4 steps, you are ready for automation! You made better requirements, reduced steps, optimized, and made it faster. Now you just need to automate and make it go BRRRRRRRRRR.

His genius is in the manufacturing like he said. Thats why he is dominating the market. When you design and procure under one corporate umbrella then your supply chain issues and inefficiencies are minimized. SpaceX sends a Dragon to the ISS on a booster, 2nd stage, engines, avionics all designed and manufactured in-house! NOBODY in the business does this! Meanwhile Boeing uses a booster and upper stage designed by Lockheed, powered by Aerojet-Rocketdyne, launched by ULA, and that's just the tip of the iceberg in terms of subcontracting. Even though legacy space is slow and expensive it still has favor when it comes to government contracts because of the massive job infrastructure needed to pump congressional districts.

The Five Step Process. - Musk
1) Make your requirements less dumb. Your requirements ARE dumb, even or possibly because a smart person gave them to you unquestioned.
2)Try very hard to delete the part or process. If you aren't forced to add stuff back in, you are not deleting enough. If the part or process does not have a current persons name attached to it, it is suspect. A requirement must be able to be defended by contemporaries who must own those requirements.
3) Simplify and Optimize. Make it more efficient.
4) Accelerate cycle or iteration time.
5) Automate.

Note; these must be done IN ORDER. There is no use in automating, or optimizing, something that should have been audited and deleted in previous steps.

I've had experience with similar experiences and have encountered major backlash for suggesting that a procedure or part should simply be omitted in a process. In the end, I turned out to be correct about 90% of the time, but I was still considered more of a saboteur than an enabler.

I've worked with chemicals such as hydrazine, cyanide, nitrous oxides, chlorates and such. I definitely have a respect for the potentials of these different chemicals, but how toxic they are depends on the type of exposure one experiences. It is often familiar chemicals one deals with on a daily basis that cause us more harm because they are considered safe. Everything depends on the context of the situation.

To the point about nozzle diameter to thrust ratio, this is basically a function of chamber pressure. Interestingly, both maximizing chamber pressure (because of scaling of tension stress vs diameter at a fixed pressure in a cylindrical combustion chamber) and maximizing useful nozzle area packing (basically circle packing density for n>2) favor a large number of relatively small engines, assuming you also care about engine TWR

Hey guys, regarding your comments about the high level of noise in the high bay. Have you considered that it is basically a giant tinny echo chamber. I think you could really improve that working area by spraying some sound deadening foam on the metal skins of that bay. It would still echo, but at a much more human friendly level (use a material that will not flake and corrupt the work). Another benefit would be some degree of temperature insulation and condensation inhibition. I'm sure a lot of those guys are wearing foam ear plugs (or should be) which filter out a lot of the tinny echoing so it's not quite as clammoring and confusing as it would be otherwise. And I realize that coating the skin of the bay would be time consuming and expensive, but it could really improve the work space. It's not a REAL consideration. But perhaps next time the FAA has given you a moratorium and the guys have some time on their hands it can be a plan B task. Just a thought. And by the way, I would consider quitting my job today and moving to Texas to work in any capacity for Elon's vision. I think about it quite a bit. To be part of that. Money isn't everything. I never got a degree for the knowledge I obtained in industry. I just did it. And then I got older. Now I can't even apply for jobs that I could do because I don't have a piece of paper showing that I know things. I was laid off during the last recession, and now I drive a bus. I used to operate metal fabrication equipment in a shipyard. I'd rather be a laborer at SpaceX on many days. I love my clients, mostly elderly people, so it IS rewarding. But NOT exciting or inspiring. Im 57 years young and still considering a move to Texas just to be part of the next phase of man's exploration.  Love these videos, it's the next best thing. ELON's 5 steps:
1) 13:34 - Make requirements less dumb
2) 13:56 - Try very hard to delete the part or process - if you're not adding parts back in you haven't deleted enough
2.1) 15:58 - Whatever requirement or constraint you have it must come with a name not a department
3) 17:20 - Simplify or optimize - Never optimize a part or process that should not exist.
4) 21:32 - Accelerate cycle time - Go faster - Only after step 1-3
5) 22:00 - Automate
5.1) 24:49 - (Stop) Too much in process testing.
